task_body_text:
We're sorry but the study is currently offline as the University is conducting a major upgrade to the database used to store the experimental data.

The update is expected to take until 8pm on tonight (Tuesday 30th). We will monitor how long the update takes and try to make the experiment available as soon as possible once it's finished.
We shall update this message if the database update takes longer than expected.

text: Curse Words and the Clock: How Expletives Alter Our Sense of Time

task_body_text:
We're really sorry but the study is only recruiting native English speakers.

As you indicated that you are not a native English speaker we cannot allow you to continue.

To end the experiment, simply close your browser window.

This study is investigation how people's perception of the passing of time changes within a situation.

Within the next task, you will initially see a cross in the centre of the screen to direct your gaze. The cross will be replaced by either a written word, a spoken word, or both togehter. Regardless of how the stimuli is presented, they will last for either 1.5 seconds (a long period) or 0.5 seconds (a short period). The stimuli will only be one of these two options. When the stimuli ends, you will be presented with two response buttons.

All you have to do is state whether the stimuli you heard lasted for a long (1.5 seconds) or short (0.5 seconds) period of time.

The buttons below allow you to play a tone that lasts for either 0.5 or 1.5 seconds to give you an idea of how long each is, please click a button below if you wish.



You will first complete a number of training trials designed to teach you the difference between a long and short audio tone. These trials do not include swear words.

When you are ready to start, please press 'Start' below.

You are about to start the main experimental trials which do include swear words.

These trials work in the same way as the training trials you have just completed. However, the length the stimuli word(s) are presented for now differs in length.


Rather than deciding whether the stimuli word you see/hear was simply 'long' or 'short' in duration, you now must decide if the word was closer to the 'long' or to the 'short' tone you heard during the previous training phase. If you think it was closer to the 0.5 second 'short' stimuli, click the 'Short' button or if you think it was closer to the 1.5 seconds 'long' stimuli, click the 'Long' button.

As a reminder: you will initially see a cross in the centre of the screen (which you should focus on). The cross will disappear and you may see a written word, hear a spoken word or hear and say a set of words. When the stimuli word(s) have been presented you will be given the two response buttons (short and long).

The task is broken up into several blocks and you will be given a break between blocks. When you are ready to start the experimental trials, please click 'Start' below.

Thank you for completing the first block, you may now have a short break if you wish. Please do not change to a different screen or look at your phone though. When you are ready to start the next block please press Continue below.

Thank you for completing the second block, you may now have a short break if you wish. Please do not change to a different screen or look at your phone though. When you are ready to start the next block please press Continue below.

Thank you for completing the third block, you may now have a short break if you wish. Please do not change to a different screen or look at your phone though. When you are ready to start the next block please press Continue below.
Thank you for completing the fourth block, you have now completed all blocks within this task. When you are ready, please press Next to move to the next task in the study.
Thank you for completing the valence ratings. When you are ready, please press Next to move to the next task in the study.
Thank you for completing the arousal ratings. When you are ready, please press Next to move to the next task in the study.

Thank you for making the previous ratings. We now just need to record the audio level you used during the study so that we can control for any effect of different audio levels between participants from affecting our results. To run this check simply click the button below.

text: Curse Words and the Clock: How Expletives Alter Our Sense of Time

task_body_text:
Thank you for completing the study, we really do appreciate you taking the time to do so. Before you close the study, there are two things left to do:

(1) Save your data
If we could ask you to download your data by clicking the button below and saving it to your computer. This will ensure that, as this study was run online, if there were any issues with your data uploading to the server we can use the saved file to manually add your data to the final dataset, ensuring your time wasn't wasted and/or the results of our study impacted (and you get to see what a raw data file actually looks like!). If you haven't heard from us within one month, feel free to delete the file from your computer as it will mean everything uploaded correctly.



Note: If the button doesn't work for any reason, you can save your data by pressing Ctrl+S (Cmd+S on a Mac).

(2) Gain SONA Credit
If you received a pop-up message above about your SONA ID not being stored correctly, or there is no button below, please email c.g.dobson@pgr.reading.ac.ukÂ to let Chris know you've completed the study and he will award you your credit manually. Otherwise, simply click the button below to return to SONA and automatically receive your credit.
